metadata.title: Effect of promoter Ce on silver-molybdenum-phosphate catalysts for selective oxidation of propane to acrolein

(B) EPR spectra of Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalyst treated under different conditions: (1) used catalysts; (2) fresh catalysts; (3) the catalysts treated with O2 flow at 773K for 15min and then cooled to room temperature in N2 flow. Fig. 6 XPS spectra of catalysts: (1) Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x ; (2) Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y ; (3) Ce0.3Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y ; (4) Ce0.5Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y . Fig. 7 TPD profiles of catalysts: (1) Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x ; (2) Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x ; (3) Ce0.5Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x . Fig. 8 Relationship of the Mo5+ concentration with the catalytic performance. Fig. 9 Relationship of the H2 consumption with the catalytic performance. ACR: acrolein; PA: propionaldehyde; AT: acetone; C2: C2H6, C2H4, and acetaldehyde; CO x : CO and CO2. Table 3 Physicochemical properties of (Ce n )Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts Catalysts BET area (g/m2) Surface composition by XPS Relative concentration of Mo5+ by EPR (a.u.) Ag/Mo Ce/Mo P/Mo Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x 10.6 0.36 – 0.33 21.9 Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x 15.7 0.42 0.33 0.34 38.4 Ce0.3Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x 16.3 0.44 0.45 0.36 46.2 Ce0.5Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x 18.8 0.50 0.55 0.36 55.4 Effect of promoter Ce on silver-molybdenum-phosphate catalysts for selective oxidation of propane to acrolein Xin Zhang a ∗ Hui-lin Wan b Wei-zheng Weng b Xiao-dong Yi b a State Key Laboratory of C1 Chemistry and Technology, Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, PR China b State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry for Solid Surfaces, Department of Chemistry, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, PR China * Corresponding author. Tel.: +86-10-6772592; fax: +86-10-62792122. Graphic A series of Me n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y (Me=Cu, Zn, Mn, W, Ce, Pr, Nd) and Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts were prepared. The addition of Ce to Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts improved the catalytic performance in selective oxidation of propane to acrolein, and Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts showed the highest acrolein selectivity (28.7%) and yield (4.4%). The physicochemical properties of Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x and Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x (n=0.1–0.5) catalysts have been comparatively characterized by BET, XRD, H2-TPR, XPS, EPR and C3H8(C3H6)-TPD. Significant differences in physicochemical properties between Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x and Ce doped Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts have been observed, which is due to the formation of the redox cycle (Ce3++Mo6+⇔Ce4++Mo5+) in the Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalyst. Such effect modified the reducibility, the concentration of Mo5+, the activation of propane and the transformation of possible intermediate propene to acroelin, which in return greatly influenced the catalytic performance of Ce doped Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts in selective oxidation of propane to acroelin. The proper addition of Ce to Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalyst improved the acrolein selectivity and yield. Keywords Propane Selective oxidation Acrolein Redox cycle 1 Introduction The selective oxidation of light alkane to oxygenate is attractive because it is potential utilization of cheap row materials [1–3]. A great deal of research has already been done so far to achieve selective oxidation of propane to acrolein and/or acrylic acid by using multi-component oxide catalysts, which are based on vanadium and/or molybdenum [1–3]. The redox properties of catalysts always play important roles in activity and selectivity in selective oxidation of propane, because the selective oxidation of propane usually processes via Mars van Krevelen mechanism. It is well known that promoters could modify the redox properties of the catalysts, which in return determine the activity and selectivity in selective oxidation of propane. The best catalyst for selective oxidation of propane to acrolein obtained up to now are BiMoVO multi-compound catalysts with the Keggin structure developed by Moro-oka and coworkers [3–6]. They observed that the molybdenum component was necessary for good activity and selectivity to acrolein. The vanadium component improved propane conversion and the addition of Ag to BiMoVO significantly enhanced acrolein selectivity [3–6]; 65% acrolein selectivity with 13% propane conversion was obtained on the optimized Ag0.01Bi0.85Mo0.54V0.45O4 catalysts [4]. Baerns et al. [7] reported that acrolein selectivity amounted to 34 and 20% (yield of 3.2 and 2.7%) when Ag0.01Bi0.85Mo0.54V0.45O4/Ca7Bi5Mo12O x and Ag0.01Bi0.85Mo0.54V0.45O4/Mg7Bi5Mo12O x catalysts were used, respectively. However, almost no acrolein was formed on Ag0.01Bi0.85Mo0.54V0.45O4/Me x O y (Me x O y =Al2O3, TiO2, SiO2) catalysts. The difference in catalytic performance could be due to oxygen species involved in selective oxidation of propane to acrolein, influencing the reaction mechanism. Teng and Kobayashi [8] observed that the addition of K+ to the Fe/SiO2 catalysts appreciably enhanced propane conversion along with high acrolein selectivity. Adjacency of Fe and K on the silica surface seemed to be important for the high oxygenate yield. The most effective catalysts for propane oxidation to acrylic acid are Mo-V-Te-Nb-O catalysts reported by Ushikubo et al. [10], Lin [2] and Lin and Linsen [9,11,12]. The substitution of Sb for Te in the Mo-V-Te-Nb-O catalyst decreased propane conversion and acrylic acid selectivity but its overall performance is quite good [2]. Takahashi et al. [13] found that the addition of K to Mo-V-Sb-Nb-O improved propane conversion. Li et al. [14] reported that the H3PMo12O40(Py) catalyst reduced by pyridine showed higher catalytic performance in propane oxidation to acrylic acid than the unreduced H3PMo12O40 catalyst. The H3PMo12O40(Py) catalyst is assumed to the highly restrain orthorhombic secondary structure against reoxidation, and Lewis acid site was generated with the formation of the primary oxygen-deficient Keggin structure. VPO is another promising catalyst for selective oxidation of propane to arylic acid. A lot of works have been done about the effect of promoters on the catalytic performance and properties of VPO. Deng and coworkers [18,19] reported that the addition of Zr to the VPO catalyst could significantly enhanced acrylic acid selectivity. Cheng et al. [20] reported that 0.01wt.% Ce doped VPO showed 18.8% yield acrylic acid, which is the highest acrylic acid yield reported on VPO catalysts so far. Wang et al. [21] investigated the influence of promoters (Co, Bi, Mo, Te, Nd, B) on the VPO catalyst. They observed that the addition of such promoters could not improve acrylic acid selectivity. In order to develop effective catalysts for selective oxidation of propane, systematic studies on the effects of promoters should be done. In the present work, Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x and Me doped Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x (Me=Cu, Zn, W, Mn, Ce, Pr, Nd) catalysts were prepared. The performance of these catalysts in selective oxidation of propane to acrolein has been tested. The results show that the promoter Ce obviously enhanced propane conversion and acrolein selectivity. In order to clarify the role of promoter Ce, physicochemical properties of the Ce-doped and undoped catalysts such as the structure, the redox properties, the Mo6+/Mo5+ ratio, and the interaction between propane and the catalysts have been comparatively characterized by BET, XRD, TPR, XPS, EPR and TPD technology, etc. and the transformation of possible intermediate propene to acrolein has been also investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x (Ag/Mo/P=0.3/0.5/0.3, mol ratio) catalyst and Me n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x (Me/Ag/Mo/P=n/0.3/0.5/0.3, mol ratio, Me=Cu, Zn, W, Mn, Ce, Pr, Nd) catalysts were, respectively, prepared by the method of grinding (NH4)H2PO4, MoO3, Ag2O and MeO x powder (such as CeO2, ZnO, CuO, etc.) with certain amount of deionized water. The samples were dried overnight in air at 383K. After drying, the samples were calcinated at 623K for 5h and then at 823K for 12h. 2.2 Catalytic testing The catalytic test was carried out at atmospheric pressure in a continuous flow system with a fixed bed quartz tubular reactor (i.d.=6mm). To minimize possible homogeneous reactions, the space of the reactor up and down the catalyst bed (0.5g, 60–80mesh) was filled with quartz wool. The exit gas were heated to 393K to prevent products condensation. The feedstock and products were analyzed with two on-line gas chromatographs with three columns, TDX-601 column and Al2O3 column impregnated with squalane (102-GC, TCD) for the separation of C3H8, C3H6, C2H4, C2H6, CO, CO2, and GDX-103 column (103-GC FID) for the separation of acrolein, acetone and propanal, etc. 2.3 Characterization The BET surface area of catalysts was measured by a ST-03 adsorptionmeter. The phase structures of the catalysts were identified by Rigaku Rotflex D/Max-C powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD) with Cu Kα (λ=0.15046nm). Both the temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments and the temperature-programmed desorption experiments (TPD) were carried out using a temperature-programmed reaction-mass spectrometer (Omnistar GSD 3000) instrument. In the TPR experiments, the sample (ca. 100mg) was exposed to a 20ml/min 5% H2/N2 flow, and heated at rate of 10K/min. For the TPD experiments, the sample was pretreated in 20ml/min propane (propene) flow for 30min at room temperature (RT), and then He flow was switched to purge the gas phase propane (propene). The desorption was performed from RT to 923K at a heating rate of 10K/min. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed by VG ESCLAB MK-II spectrometer wit Al Kα (1486.6eV, 10.1kV). The spectra were referenced with respect to C 1s line at 284.7eV. The measurement error is ±0.2eV. The electronic paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were obtained by a Brucker 200D-SCR spectrometer at RT. The klystron frequency was 9.6GHz and magnetic field modulation was 100KHz. 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic performance 3.1.1 Propane oxidation The performance of the catalysts in selective oxidation of propane to acrolein is shown in Table 1 . The blank reactor did not show activity in oxidation of propane, indicating that the homogeneous reaction could not make significant contribution to the heterogeneous oxidation of propane under our experiment conditions. Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalyst showed 5.6% acrolein selectivity and 67.9% propene selectivity with 10.9% propane conversion. The addition of promoter such as Cu, Zn, W, Mn, Ce, Pr, Nd to Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts changed catalytic activity and products distribution in selective oxidation of propane. In all the investigated catalysts, Ce doped Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts showed higher propane conversion and higher acrolein selectivity. In the case of Ce doped Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts, propane conversion and products distribution depended on the Ce-content. With the Ce-content increasing, propane conversion increased; acrolein selectivity firstly increased and simultaneously propene selectivity decreased and CO x selectivity increased. The maximal 4.4% acrolein yield with 28.7% acroelin selectivity was obtained on Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y . The reaction temperature had great influence on propane conversion and products distribution of the Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalyst in selective oxidation of propane to acrolein (Fig. 1 ). When the reaction temperature was elevated, propane conversion increased. The maximal acrolein selectivity and yield were observed with the rising of reaction temperature, while propene selectivity monotonically decreased. Deep oxidation products CO x became favorable at the high temperatures. The effect of space velocity on the catalytic performance of Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalyst in selective oxidation of propane was also investigated. As can be seen in Fig. 2 , propane conversion and products distribution varied as a function of space velocity. With the increase in space velocity, propane conversion decreased, while propene selectivity monotonously increased and acroelin selectivity gave maximal value at the space velocity of 2400ml/(gcath). In addition, the decrease of CO x selectivity was observed with increasing space velocity. These Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts showed good performance for acrolein formation in selective oxidation of propane. This work thus focuses on these catalysts. 3.1.2 Propene oxidation It is well known that the primary products of a given reaction can be discriminated from high-order products by extrapolating products selectivity to zero conversion. Primary products have non-zero intercepts, while secondary and high-order products have zero intercepts [15]. In the case of selective oxidation of propane over Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts (Fig. 2), it is clear that the dominant primary products was propene because propene selectivity gradually increased with the decrease in propane conversion. Table 2 shows that the results of propene oxidation over Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x and Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts. Acrolein and CO x were main products in propene oxidation. The addition of Ce enhanced propene conversion and acrolein yield. Compared with Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalyst, acrolein selectivity was higher on Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts when the Ce/Mo ratio was varied from 0.05 to 0.3; however, it became lower as the Ce/Mo ratio increased to 0.5. In the case of Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts, the maximal acrolein selectivity and yield were observed on Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalyst, and acrolein selectivity and yield monotonously decreased when the Ce/Mo ratio increased. An increase in CO x selectivity was observed with the Ce-content. It can be noted that propene conversion almost kept constant as the Ce/Mo ratio increased from 0.1 to 0.5, which might be due to the total consumption of O2 taking place. By combining the propane oxidation and propene oxidation data, propene was primary product that was then oxidized to acrolein over these catalysts in selective oxidation of propane. The proper addition of Ce in the catalysts enhanced the conversion of propene to acrolein, but the oxidation of propene to deep oxidation products CO x was favorable on the catalysts with Ce/Mo=0.5. 3.2 Characterization 3.2.1 BET surface area and XRD characterization The BET surface area of these catalysts is shown in Table 3 . Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x had the lowest surface area of 10.6m2/g. The surface area of Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts was higher than that of Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x , and slightly increased with increasing Ce-content. The XRD patterns of Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y and Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . MoO3 and AgMoO2PO4 were main phases in Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts. In the case of Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts, new phases CeMoO6 and CeO2 were found. In addition, it can be noted that the peak intensities of CeMoO6 and CeO2 increased with increasing Ce-content, indicating that the amount of CeMoO6 and CeO2 increased. 3.2.2 TPR characterization The TPR profiles of Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts, Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalyst, pure MoO3 and pure CeO2 are presented in Fig. 4 . The TPR profile of pure MoO3 showed two reduction peaks at 926 and 1042K, corresponding to the step-wise reduction of Mo6+⇒Mo4+ and Mo4+⇒Mo0, respectively [22,23]. CeO2 showed two reduction peaks at ca. 811 and 1035K with respect to the reduction of Ce4+⇒Ce3+⇒Ce0 [24]. Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts and Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts exhibited the low temperature reduce peak (<500K) and the high temperature reduce peaks (>700K). The low temperature reduction peak near 420K may be due to the reduction of Ag+⇒Ag0 [25]. The high temperature reduction peaks could be assigned to the contributions of the reduction of Mo- and Ce-oxides. The reduction peaks (>700K) shifted to the lower temperature when Ce was added to Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts, and they monotonically shifted toward the lower temperature with increasing Ce-content. In order to estimate the H2 consumption, the area of TPR profile was integrated. The H2 consumption increased in the sequence Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y <Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y <Ce0.3Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y <Ce0.5Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalyst. The results reveal that the reducibility of (Ce n )Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts improved with increasing Ce-content. 3.2.3 EPR characterization The EPR spectroscopy was used to investigate the presence and change of Mo5+ and Ce3+ in these catalysts (Fig. 5 ). The spectra of the catalysts exhibited signals with g 1=1.94 and g 2=1.89 attributed to Mo5+ [26,27]. No hyperfine structure due to Mo5+ (S=1/2, I=5/2) was observed, indicating that Mo5+ was not sufficiently apart from one another and the Mo5+ strong interaction had eliminated the hyperfine structure. The EPR signal at g 3=1.98 due to Ce3+ was also found in Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts [28,29]. The formulate [I i (ΔH pp) i 2]/[I(ΔH pp)2]standardsample could be used to roughly estimate relative concentration of Mo5+ in the catalysts, in which Ii is intensity of peaks and ΔH pp the line width at peak to peak maximum [32–35]. The results are shown in Table 3. The relative concentration of Mo5+ increased following the order of Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y <Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y <Ce0.3Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y <Ce0.5Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalyst. Fig. 5B gives the EPR spectra of Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y treated under different conditions. Compared with the fresh catalyst, the EPR spectrum of the used catalyst showed broad and strong peak. After the catalyst was treated in O2 flow at 773K for 15min and then sealed in a glass tube, the intensity of Mo5+ remarkably reduced. The results suggest that Mo5+/Mo6+ and Ce3+/Ce4+ were involved in the activation of molecular oxygen and oxidation of propane. 3.2.4 XPS characterization In this study, oxidation state and relative surface concentration of composition have been investigated by using XPS. The XPS spectra of pure MoO3 are used to identify the possible change of the state of Mo. The binding energy (BE) of Mo 3d5/2 on MoO3 is 233.5eV. The BE of Mo 3d5/2 on Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x was about 233.1eV (Fig. 6 ). Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts showed the lower BE of Mo 3d5/2 than Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalyst. The BE of Mo 3d5/2 on Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y decreased from 232.8 to 232.5eV with increasing Ce-content, suggesting that the electronic density around Mo nucleus increased, in other words, the coordinatively unsaturated Mo increased on the surface. In addition, shoulder peaks near 234.5eV were observed, which may be assigned to Mo 5+ 3d 3/2 . Fig. 6 also gives Ce 3d XPS spectra on Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts. The peaks near 915.6 and 910.5eV were assigned to Ce4+ [16,17]. The peak at 885.0eV was due to Ce3+ [16,17]. With increasing Ce-content, the BE of Ce slightly fluctuated. The value corresponding to relative surface concentration is presented in Table 3. Surface concentration was heavily dependent on the Ce-content in the catalysts. In the case of Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts, we note an increase in Ag and Ce concentrations, respectively, with increasing Ce-content. In addition in, the ratio of Ag/Mo on Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts was higher than that on Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x . 3.2.5 C3H8-TPD and C3H6-TPD characterization In order to investigate the interaction between C3H8(C3H6) and the catalysts, the temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments were carried out. The TPD profiles are shown in Fig. 7 . C3H8-TPD profiles showed one desorption peak on both Ce doped Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y and undoped Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalyst, indicating that there was one kind of active sites for C3H8 adsorption on these catalysts. Compared with Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x , the desorption peak shifted toward the higher temperature on Ce doped Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts. The results suggest that the addition of Ce enhanced the interaction between C3H8 and the catalysts. In the case of C3H6 desorption, one peak due to C3H6 desorption was observed on both Ce doped Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x and Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts. The desorption peak temperature shifted to higher temperature with the increase in the Ce-content, indicating that the promoter Ce enhanced C3H6 adsorption. 4 Discussion The addition of promoter Ce in the catalysts modified the physicochemical properties, which in turn influenced the catalytic performance in selective oxidation of propane to acroelin. The significant difference in physicochemical properties among the catalysts has been observed. The promoter Ce improved the reducibility, increased the relative concentration of Mo5+, modified the surface composition, and enhanced the C3H8(C3H6) adsorption on the catalysts. Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts had higher catalytic performance in selective oxidation of propane to acrolein than Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalyst. Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y showed the highest 4.4% acrolein yield with 28.7% acroelin selectivity. In addition, the proper addition of Ce could enhance the transformation of possible intermediate propene to acrolein. The variation of such properties of Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts could be due to the interaction between Mo and Ce in Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts. Both Mo5+ and Ce3+ were detected on Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts. The redox potential of Mo6+/Mo5+ and Ce4+/Ce3+ is about 0.3eV, and −1.61eV, respectively. Both Ce and Mo are able to activate/store oxygen and transform/release oxygen species. Hence, the redox cycle (Ce3++Mo6+⇔Ce4++Mo5+) can exist, improving the transfer of electron and oxygen species. With the increase in the Ce-content, the relative concentration of Mo5+ gradually increased, the lattice oxygen deficient sites around the coordinatively unsaturated Mo ion enhanced [14]. The more the lattice oxygen deficient sites, the easier the diffusion of oxygen [30,31]. Thus, the reducibility of the catalysts improved with the increase in the Ce-content. In order to elucidate such changes to be responsible for the catalytic performance of Ce doped Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts, several methods have been employed. The catalytic performance has been identified in terms of specific activity (specific activity=mol propane converted (m2 s−1)) and specific yield (specific selectivity=mol acrolein obtained (m2 s−1)). The relationships of Ce-content with the reducibility and the concentration of Mo5+ and catalytic performance are presented in Figs. 8 and 9 , respectively. A clear correlation was observed between the catalytic performance and physicochemical properties. With the increase in Ce/Mo ratio in these catalysts, the Mo5+ concentration gradually increased. The specific activity monotonously increased with the Mo5+ concentration; the acrolein specific yield showed a volcano shape curve and gave the maximal value on the Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts (Fig. 8). Likewise, an increase in H2 consumption was observed with increasing Ce-content, and specific activity increased and the maximal acrolein specific yield was achieved on the Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts (Fig. 9). In selective oxidation of propane to acrolein on Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts, the oxygen deficient site around coordinatively unsaturated Mo5+ reacted with molecular oxygen to form lattice oxygen species that are active species for propane activation; simultaneously, the coordinatively unsaturated Mo5+ was oxidized to Mo6+ (Mars van Krevelen redox mechanism) [3]. The enhancement of reducibility is in favor of this process. Therefore, the more the concentration of Mo5+ and the stronger reducibility are, the higher the specific activity. On the other hand, propene was the intermediate for the formation of acrolein in selective oxidation of peopane. The transformation of propene to acrolein will be mostly determined by the interaction of propene with the catalyst surface. As can be seen in Sections 3.2.5 and 3.1.2, the proper addition of Ce to the catalysts resulted in the enhancement of propene adsorption and transformation of propene to acroelin. Therefore, high acroelin selectivity and yield were obtained on Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalyst. However, owing to much stronger interaction between propene and the Ce0.5Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalyst, and the higher reducibility, intermediate propene could easily suffer deep oxidation to CO x . Consequently, acrolein selectivity and yield was decreased on the Ce0.5Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalyst in selective oxidation of propane. 5 Conclusions In conclusion, the addition of promoter Ce to Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x modified the physicochemical properties such as the reducibility, the concentration of Mo5+, surface composition, the propane adsorption as well as the transformation of intermediate propene to acrolein, which in turn determined the catalytic performance of these catalysts in selective oxidation of propane to acrolein. The maximal acrolein selectivity and yield were obtained on the Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalyst. The formation of redox cycle (Ce3++Mo6+⇔Ce4++Mo5+) in Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalysts accounts for the change of physicochemical properties and performance of these catalysts. coredata.dc:description: A series of Me n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y (Me=Cu, Zn, Mn, W, Ce, Pr, Nd) and Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts were prepared. The addition of Ce to Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts improved the catalytic performance in selective oxidation of propane to acrolein, and Ce0.1Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts showed the highest acrolein selectivity (28.7%) and yield (4.4%). The physicochemical properties of Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x and Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x (n=0.1–0.5) catalysts have been comparatively characterized by BET, XRD, H2-TPR, XPS, EPR and C3H8(C3H6)-TPD. Significant differences in physicochemical properties between Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x and Ce doped Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts have been observed, which is due to the formation of the redox cycle (Ce3++Mo6+⇔Ce4++Mo5+) in the Ce n Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O y catalyst. Such effect modified the reducibility, the concentration of Mo5+, the activation of propane and the transformation of possible intermediate propene to acroelin, which in return greatly influenced the catalytic performance of Ce doped Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalysts in selective oxidation of propane to acroelin. The proper addition of Ce to Ag0.3Mo0.5P0.3O x catalyst improved the acrolein selectivity and yield.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of promoter Ce on silver-molybdenum-phosphate catalysts for selective oxidation of propane to acrolein
